ReportSection.name: Information
ReportSection.title: EPIC-AT Early Career Researcher Awards in Patient-Oriented Research
ReportSection.Static:
Information Package

Instructions

  1. The application is comprised of an online application form and supporting documents detailed below. Late or incomplete applications will not be reviewed.
  2. Applicants are strongly recommended to complete the EPIC-AT HRTP Fellowship application (Section C of this package in either English or French) using preferred word processing software.
  3. Once you are ready to submit your application online, if you have not already done so, you must register with the AGE-WELL Forum Research Portal at https://forum.agewell-nce.ca/index.php/Special:HQPRegister (the form will ask for your name and email). After you submit the registration form, the system will create an account and send your credentials to the email address you provided. Once you login, you will have to reset your temporary password.
  4. The “My Applications” link is in the top right of the page you will reach after resetting your password.
  5. The Forum is open and you will be able to see and select “EPIC-AT 2023.” Copy your application material and upload supporting documents to the AGE-WELL Forum Research Portal website by 5pm ET on 31 January, 2023.
  6. Notice of Admissions will be received in March 2023. Expected start date of fellowship is 1 April, 2023.
Contact Information: training@agewell-nce.ca

Background Information

About EPIC-AT HRTP

The Early Professionals, Inspired Careers in AgeTech Health Research Training Platform (EPIC-AT HRTP) is a national training platform that will prepare graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and early career researchers to be future leaders in digital health solutions for older adults with complex health needs.

Powered by AGE-WELL, EPIC-AT is led by researchers from 11 universities and research hospitals across 6 Canadian provinces. It is hosted at the University of Toronto. This unique platform is funded by the Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR) with additional support provided by 41 collaborating organizations from across Canada.

The competency-based, experiential learning platform is an extension of AGE-WELL’s globally-leading EPIC training program.

EPIC-AT Early Career Researcher Awards in Patient-Oriented Research

EPIC-AT is pleased offer Black, Indigenous, and racialized early career researchers funding to support patient-oriented research and patient engagement. Funding for these awards was made available through the Strategy for Patient-Oriented Research (SPOR) Supplement to CIHR Health Research Training Platforms.

EPIC-AT is built on a foundation of equity, diversity, inclusion, and accessibility. Racialized people comprise over one-fifth of the Canadian population, yet are significantly under-represented as both faculty members and senior university leaders (Cukier, 2021). Moreover, as found by an Innovation, Science, and Economic Development Canada sponsored survey, tenured faculty tend to be less racially diverse and more likely to be male.

These awards are meant to increase financial support for Black, Indigenous, and other racialized early career researchers to pursue patient-oriented research and patient engagement activities and help build their independent research programs as they pertain to digital health solutions for older adults with complex health needs.

Applicants are encouraged to review the Use of Grant Funds section of the Tri-Agency (CIHR, NSERC and SSHRC) Financial Administration Guide for a complete listing and description of allowable costs and activities.

Priority Research Areas

Visible minority and immigrant older adults are particularly susceptible to the digital divide due to the intersecting identity markers of race, class, age, and gender.

Moreover, Indigenous older adults are one of the most rapidly growing group of seniors in Canada. Due to the continued effects of colonization and systemic biases, Indigenous older adults face a higher and rising prevalence of complex health needs including multimorbidity. It is imperative to swiftly develop and implement culturally safe and appropriate solutions.

As such, EPIC-AT welcomes especially applications from those who will explicitly serve equity-deserving groups.

We expect to offer the following 1 year awards in this call:
  • 2 EPIC-AT Early Career Researcher Awards in Patient-Oriented Research at $20,000

Benefits

In addition to funding, recipients will be granted access to the EPIC-AT training and mentorship program and have an opportunity to:
  1. gain in-depth, specialized expertise in developing, implementing and evaluating digital health solutions for seniors with complex health needs
  2. access to multi-sectoral mentors and sponsors
  3. participate in value-added professional development training, internship and lab exchange opportunities
  4. network with a community of AgeTech researchers and professionals
  5. receive support to identify and attain career goals

Eligibility

  1. Indigenous, Black, and Racialized early career researcher applicants must be within the first 5 years (60 months) of a full-time academic appointment at a Canadian post-secondary institution or research institute.
  2. All applicants must be engaged in academic study/research aligned with the mission and vision of EPIC-AT.
  3. Applicants may not hold an EPIC-AT Fellowship or be part of the EPIC-AT leadership including Platform Advisory Committee members, Principle Applicants, or Co-Applicants.

Program Requirements

Reporting

Award holders are required to report on their publications, presentations, and progress made towards goals.

Recipient institutions will report on expenditures of EPIC-AT funds by submitting a Form 300 to training@agewell-nce.ca no later than April 30 of each year for the duration of the award term.

Acknowledging EPIC-AT

Recipients will acknowledge the EPIC-AT Health Research Training Platform in their presentations, publications, and other knowledge translation activities related to research conducted during their award term.

Adjudication Criteria

All applications will undergo an administrative round of review to confirm eligibility and relevance of the applicant’s research to stakeholders’ lived experiences.

Eligible applications will then be reviewed by a team of field experts using the following criteria:

Application Review Criteria

The following criteria and scoring scheme are used to evaluate the applications:

Objectives & Rationale 30%
  • the activity or project’s relevance to EPIC-AT values and mission
  • originality or novelty of proposed activity or project
  • proposal demonstrates how EDI principles and best practices inform activities
Deliverables & Feasibility 40%
  • appropriateness of the methods and theoretical approach
  • probability that the objectives will be met within the timeline proposed
  • involvement of partners or stakeholders in the design and conduct of proposed activities
  • appropriateness of requested budget and justification of proposed costs
Potential Impact 30%
  • potential positive impact on the lives of older adults and caregivers
  • the associated benefits to older adults and caregivers is feasibly described

EPIC-AT ECR Awards in Patient-Oriented Research applications will be assigned a score for each of the three criteria above, based on the following scoring table. The appropriate weighting is then applied to arrive at a final score. Applications must receive a score of 6 or higher for each of the three criteria to be recommended for funding.

Score Descriptor
8-9 Very good to excellent
6-7 Good to very good
4-5 Satisfactory to good
Below 4 Unsatisfactory
Important Dates
Forum Application Opens: December 19, 2022
Completed Applications Due: 31 January, 2023
Results Available: March 2023
Fellowship Term: 1 April 2023 – 31 March 2024

ReportSection.name: Application Form
ReportSection.Static:
1. ADMINISTRATIVE INFORMATION
Please note that the information provided here is not used to adjudicate applications and will not affect your ranking.

ReportItem.placeholder: e.g., PhD Year 1, Occupational therapy or Assistant Professor, Year 3

ReportSection.ReportItem: Academic Status and Department:{$item}

ReportItem.placeholder: Please list the institution where funds will be held

ReportSection.ReportItem: Institution/University:{$item}
Research Project Title:{$item}

Total Value of EPIC-AT Investment Requested:
(max $20,000){$item}
Is this Project/Activity Supported by Another Source of Funding? If yes, please list.{$item}
{$item}
Is Research Ethics Review Required For This Project?{$item}If yes, please note that you will be required to submit approval to training@agewell-nce.ca.

Lay Summary
The lay summary should address each of the following questions:
  1. Background: What do we already know about the problem?
  2. Objective: What question does your study address?
  3. Method: How will the research be carried out? How is this different from previous studies?
  4. Implications: How will the anticipated results improve the lives of older adults with complex health needs and/or their caregivers?
{$item}

2. OBJECTIVES AND RATIONALE

EPIC-AT is passionate about achieving real-world impact through practical and useful technologies or technology-based services and policies. We are committed to involving older people, caregivers and other relevant stakeholders in all stages of our research and development and throughout our programs. Please describe your proposed project or activity, its goals or objectives. Describe the rationale for this activity. Why is this work important? {$item}
Who are your stakeholders? How will you include them in your activities? Please discuss here your consideration of EDI and implementation of best practices. {$item}
How does your research connect to research foci of EPIC-AT? How will you include them in your activities? Please discuss here your consideration of EDI and implementation of best practices. {$item}

3. DELIVERABLES AND FEASIBILITY

Clearly describe your methodological approach and describe your research project deliverables mapped to its associated timeline. Please clearly articulate how you intend to accomplish your deliverables. Methodological Approach

Describe the type of research being undertaken e.g. technology development, review, feasibility study, pilot study, requirements analysis, prototype development, intervention study, evaluation study, etc.

Provide an overview of the approach (design/methods) you will use to meet your project objectives. Why is this an appropriate method?

{$item}

Study Milestones, Deliverables, Outputs and Outcomes

Describe the tasks and activities planned (provide detail on specific tasks to be carried out to meet the project objectives you identified above). “Activities” may include research activities, KT, innovation, commercialization, team-building and training, etc.

Provide specific timing of the various tasks, activities and milestones, where milestones are critical points in the project (e.g., completion of a task)

{$item}

4. POTENTIAL OUTCOMES & IMPACT

Potential Impact

In this section, please provide a brief statement of the potential positive impact your work will have on the lives of older adults with complex health needs and their caregivers.

As applicable, address the following:

Social innovation
What are practical benefits of your research to the wider community?

Technological innovation
What are the novel aspects and contributions of your research from a technical point of view?

Policy and practice innovation
How might policies, services and care be transformed by your research?

Scientific innovation
What are the key scientific outputs from this research?

{$item}

Impact Plan

EPIC-AT seeks to equip trainees and ECRs with the skills to translate their work into real-world impact.

While the success ultimately depends on the rate of uptake and meaningful application of knowledge or products by end users, non-traditional academic knowledge mobilization, commercialization and effective implementation of solutions are a platform goal.

Not every Fellowship or grant recipient is expected to be directly responsible for a commercial outcome or uptake of knowledge, but all projects should be actively contributing to these overall goals.

Please address your plan to ensure your work achieves the impact described in the previous section.

{$item}

ReportSection.name: Self-Identification Form

ReportItem.options: 18-24 years old|25-34 years old|35-44 years old|45-54 years old|55-64 years old|65-74 years old|75+ years old|I prefer not to answer

ReportSection.ReportItem:
Please note that the information provided here will not be shared. It will not be used to adjudicate applications and will not affect your ranking. This information is solely collected so the platform can monitor the equity performance of programs and design new measures that achieve greater equity, diversity and inclusion in the research enterprise.

All applications for fellowships require you to complete a self-identification form; however, if you would prefer not to self-identify and/or provide the requested information, you may select “I prefer not to answer" for any or all of the questions.

Any self-identification statistics shared will always be reported in aggregate form to ensure protection of the identity of any individual.

The collection of this information is an essential part of efforts to improve EDI in science and research. For further information, please see the Tri-Agency's policy on Self-Identification Data Collection in Support of EDI and Canada's 50-30 Challenge.

See the Tri-Agency's policy on Self-Identification Data Collection in Support of EDI here: https://science.gc.ca/eic/site/063.nsf/eng/h_97615.html
Age:{$item}
